sect1.title: Purpose
sect1.para: The Benchmark Manager is a service for managing analyses. It stores their meta data and handles their scheduling. It provides basic functions to create, run once or periodically, update and delete analyses. It was designed to replace the legacy Benchmark Manager of BEEN.

New Benchmark Manager is designed to be light-weight and flexible component. We replaced old, rather big plug-ins which always contained Configurator, Generator and VersionProvider classes. Now we use smaller specialized generator and evaluator pluggable modules to separate the creation and evaluation of benchmark data. These pluggable modules are commonly called BMmodules as they are generally not used by anyone else but the Benchmark Manager.

listitem.para: Command Line Interface and web interface modules provide user interface to the Benchmark Manager. They both use BenchmarkManagerInterface to display data about analyses. They also use BenchmarkManagerCallbackInterface to allow user to manually mark some analysis runs as finished (which is usually context-monitor's job).
The generator-runner task uses BenchmarkManagerCallbackInterface to report that analysis tasks have been generated.
The context-monitor task (created by the generator-runner) uses BenchmarkManagerCallbackInterface to report end of analysis run.
Benchmark Manager uses PluggableModuleManager to load used pluggable modules.
It also uses JAXB configuration parser to read the BMmodules' configuration description.
Benchmark Manager and generator-runner use Task Manager to plan new analysis run.
There is also connection to the Results Repository through generator and evaluator pluggable modules which might need to create some datasets and triggers in the Results Repository.
A single BEEN service - BenchmarkManagerService and BenchmarkManagerImplementation
Two tasks - generator-runner (Benchmark Manager specific) and context-monitor (which can be used for other purposes)
Several meta data objects (Analysis, AnalysisState, BMmodule, ...)
Attached (pluggable) BMmodules can also be considered part of Benchmark Manager although they can be removed or added even on runtime.
